reviewText: A towering achievement, 'Babel,' provides a great alchemy. Last year's best films often had twisty, interlocking plots that came together from fragmented lives. 'Babel' continues this trend where few films have gone since. Not only that but the beautiful cinematography (courtesy Rodrigo Prieto) and the wonderfully placed soundtrack from Gustavo Santanella (both of 'Brokeback Mountain' fame) are just a few of the nuances in this brilliant movie. Having some of the feel of 'Syriana,' 'Babel' digs deeper. Both movies are grand and comprehensive with a theme: 'Babel' does for communication gaps what 'Syriana' did for the world oil industry and all its consuming problems--no pun intended! If movies are to give us escapist fare or illuminating transcendence, then 'Babel' succeeds in both by offering absorbing protagonists in a tight and ingenious story. Unlike 'Syriana,' a very good movie, 'Babel' doesn't exhaust us mentally. Beyond that, there's no comparison. 'Babel' is a magnificent and brilliant film that never stops fermenting resources.Briefly, Richard and Susan Jones (Brad Pitt and Kate Blanchet) are traveling in a tour bus through the desert of Morocco. Along the nearby cliffs, two boys are testing a questionable rifle their father obtained from a Japanese hunter. They are shooting at rocks and other targets, skeptical of the claims that it can shoot up to three kilometers. The results seem to support their doubts until the younger boy shoots at a tour bus coming on a twisty, desert road below them. The result is that Susan is shot, barely discerning its impact at first. The movie then splits its focus in four pieces: The Japanese man has a deaf daughter (Koji Yakusho) who is isolated by her handicap, and typically, is frustrated by her luck with dating. Revelations are made about her father as well as the mother's mysterious death, which is given one rendering by the daughter, another by the father. Ties are made to the Japanese hunter with the gun found at the boys' home. Meanwhile, the boys' benign action creates an International incident. The Post 9/11 world is, understandably, nervous at the pull of a trigger. Fearing repercussions from America, the Moroccan government descends on the boys' family and community with terse language and much firepower. Misunderstandings are stretched to the breaking point. Back home in the US, the Smith's caretaker, an illegal immigrant from Mexico, cares about the two Smith children under her wing, but she won't miss a key relative's wedding in her native Mexico. Her solution? Take the kids over the border with her nephew, Santiago, driving the way to the fiesta. Her drunken nephew partly is responsible for making the return a living hell. (Things don't translate well at the border patrol.) Then, of course, there's the Smiths, who must break through the Arab language barrier and forget that the Third World doesn't offer the amenities, including health care, the way it does at home. Kindness translates in any language, and whenever it's present in the movie, `Babel' is partly defeated.To tell the details of 'Babel' is a real spoiler, so I leave you to watch it. But one development is a testament to the movie's marvelousness. When we go to the discothèque in Japan, we hear and feel the silence and alienation Chieko goes through as she can only imitate others' bumping and grinding. We can see how painfully aware she becomes in her silence as she notices her fellow deaf friend stealing her boyfriend escort. Effective to every detail, the acting, editing, writing, and directing (Guillermo Arriaga and Alejandro Ina'rrita, respectively for the latter two) make 'Babel' a masterpiece. In an age of instant text messaging, 'Babel' reminds us of our frailty in ample situations that get "lost in translation". And a world of misunderstandings can take place with language barriers. (Highly recommended)

reviewText: This movie is incredible.  The story had me riveted from the beginning.  A cosmic version of the movie Crash on a grander scale.  This journey takes us to many different parts of the world.  The cinematography is wonderful and the grittiness is so very real.  In this movie you are not getting a santized view of the world we live in.  This movie is so much bigger than just Brad Pitt.In Babel we are quickly thrust into a series of terrible events that seems to have no end.  Just when you are hoping for something to turn better it doesn't.  From the beginning portrayl of two Morrocan brothers who are entrusted to take care of the families livelihood it becomes apparent how much children are the same.  The wonderful acting almost had me feeling the warm air of the desert as I began to feel if I was there.  I quickly felt a lump in my stomach as the inevitable happens and the horrendous journey begins.  I will save the story for you the viewer but please be ready from an emotional joyride.What I think captivated me most was that Babel wasn't watered down.  It was real, incredibely real.  From the Middle East, to Japan, and then to Mexico the stories seemed almost to real.  Combined with the acting I was quickly thrown over the edge.  It's almost hard to imagine the magnitude of such a film bringing so many cultures together.  Yet it did and it did very well.  Everyone played a part that you could imagine would be real.Overall this movie is a must see.  Don't get ready for some happy celebration that will make you feel good.  This movie is distrubing...and if your not paying attention you will miss something.  Your not going to find much lighthearted fun.  Even when there is a joyful scene a serious touch of reality comes.  When you see children playing a game where they attempt to catch a chicken that goes from excitment to grief on the child's face when they see the real fate of the chicken they just caught.  The Blu-ray version won't leave you stunned for the most part.  It lacks any special features that would make it stand out.  The hd picture is okay but not stunning.  I would say if cosmetics aren't very big for you to go get the standard dvd version.  Generally this movie is worth many awards and hopefully it gets it's place in cinematic history.

reviewText: There are so many things wrong with this movie that I find it hard to understand the number of positive reviews. This is mediocrity trying to pass as an enlightened film on how we are all connected and the global consequences of our actions. Every parent in this film was beyond irresponsible and should have had their children taken away from them.I'm suppose to believe that a well-off American couple deserts their also grieving young children to go to Morocco for "alone time" to recover from the Sudden Infant Death of their youngest child (talk about the me generation)? That this couple would leave their kids alone for weeks with the nanny (an illegal immigrant, day care provider)? That's just one of the many far-fetched steps that are used to force this movie along.The shooting of Cate Blanchet's character was messed up.  Where was the continuity manager for the movie?  She was sitting on the driver's side of the bus, yet she was shot by a bullet fired from the opposite side of the bus. However, it is shown as if the bullet comes in her side of the window (this is cartoon physics where the bullet magically goes around the object). From the angle that the kid's fired the rifle, the bullet would have gone in the front or the front side opposite the driver and oppostie where Cate was sitting.  Based on where the bullet came in the bus, the local police should have been looking at the hillside area on the left side of the bus, but they still managed to find the shell casings high on a hill in a large landscape of desert, in just a short time.  This can only happen in a movie.  She was hurt so badly that her husband, Brad Pitt, (in yet another one-two note acting job) tried to keep the bus in the small town rather than try to reach a hospital. Yet she was well enough to talk and move around some before the helicopter finally showed up many hours after she could have been at the hospital. Also, was it because they were Americans that the shooting was tagged immediately as a terrorist event? Would that have been the case if the Australians or Germans on the bus had been shot?  This whole setup reeked of "the ugly American".If one believes the premise of this movie that all the characters are tied together by the rifle, then Chieko's mother, who committed suicide by shooting herself, probably did so with the ill-fated rifle because of incest between the father and daughter (implied in the final scenes of the movie).  The father abandon's his daughter in her grief and goes to Morocco to shoot big-game (do they have any in Morocco) and leaves the rifle behind as a gift to his guide precipitating the events that bring all the families together. The guide sells the rifle to his friend for what seems like an extreme amount of money considering the circumstances in which they live.Once the kids have the rifle, they use it for what are the only believable sections of the movie.  They are told to shoot jackals to protect the family's most important possession, the goat herd.  Instead, being kids, they start shooting at rocks etc and aim at the bus because they don't believe the bullets can go that far.  Then they hide the gun and act like typical kids who have screwed up.In the mean time, even with the mother having been shot and the father calling and telling the nanny (Amelia) to stay with the kids, she decides to take them to Mexico for her son's wedding in the car driven by her clearly irresponsible nephew. Instead of staying after the wedding for a reasonable time and letting the nephew sober up, they all get back in the car and end up in trouble at the border.  Amelia then makes every imaginable mistake, putting herself and the kids in life threatening situations, only to end up deported and no longer able to see the kids she claims (strongly) to the border patrol, that she loves.This movie was an endless stream of improbable and impossible events meant to garner sympathy from the audience. It failed.  Gael Garcia Bernal and Cate Blanchett, both of whom are outstanding actors, were wasted; anyone could have played their parts.If you want a movie that shows how actions have global consequences see "Syriana". If you want a movie that makes a statement, see "Thank You For Smoking". If you want an Indie film that will make you think, see anything by Charlie Kaufmann.
summary: How does such mediocrity get 7 Academy Nominations?

reviewText: Babel is a group of three separate stories, involving four separate familes, that are all interconnected.  The central story from which the others radiate involves an American couple vacationing in Morocco, who fall victim to a random act of violence.  This gut wrenching film demonstrates both the necessity and impossibility of human communication, as well as the tragedies that can happen due to accidental or unintended mistakes.  The acting was superb, the camera work excellent, transitioning from country to country and event to event with a seamless, understandable movement.  The film won a Golden Globe for Best Drama, which I consider well deserved.

reviewText: This is riveting story telling that doesn't talk down to its audience.  Critics seem to be tired of films that interweave three or four narrative threads.  But that's often how real life works.  Our stories are rarely told in isolation, and, ala the butterfly effect, our best-intended gestures (such as making the gift of a rifle to a guide in Morocco) can have unintended consequences.  But none of that really matters when you have stories as engrossing as the four collected here.  The connections are sometimes obvious, as in the case of Richard (Brad Pitt) and Susan (Cate Blanchett); they have just lost a child and are in Morocco trying to put their marriage back together.  They have left their surviving children, a boy and a girl, in the care of their nanny, whose son is getting married in Mexico.  When Richard tells the nanny she can't have the day off, she makes the life-altering decision to drive across the border with both her young charges and her firecracker nephew (played by Gael Garcia Bernal, an alumnus of director Alejandro Inarritu's earlier masterpiece, "Amores Perros").  The story that initiates the action is that of two young Moroccan brothers, who receive a rifle from their father, with the instruction to kill the jackals that are attacking their goats.  When the younger brother takes a pot shot at a passing tour bus, Susan (Blanchett) is shot and the complex plot is set in motion.  The most tangential, yet in some ways the most provocative, thread is provided by the Japanese story, which centers on a deaf-mute young woman (played by charismatic newcomer Rinko Kikuchi), whose mother has committed suicide.  Although she lives in a culture that panders to youth, she is both physically and emotionally set off from the adults in that world--including her father--who might give her solace.  When she acts out sexually with a kindly, if somewhat disconcerted, policeman, she finally inspires a response from her distant father, the same Japanese tourist who once gave a rifle to his guide in Morocco, who then sold it to a goatherder with two sons.  This approach to film making can come off as forced (think "Crash"), but when it works (think the best films of Robert Altman), it can provide a singularly satisfying viewing experience, the sort of thing that both challenges and provokes audiences, and that keeps them coming back to the cinema.  Indeed, Inarritu is such a masterful film-maker that I wouldn't be surprised to find him on the short list for an Academy Award for directing in April.

reviewText: Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu, is turning into quite the filmmaker. Already his first two films, Amores perros and 21 Grams (which I thought was the best film of 2003) were hugh international successes, which brought much praise Inarritu's way. His new film "Babel" is equally deserving of such praise. It is one of the year's best films.As was the case with his previous films "Babel" is an interlocking character film, where we get to meet many different characters, each involved in a different storyline, which very carefully starts to intertwine all the characters together.Given that the film's title is "Babel" the movie becomes a religious epic. It is a story of love, tolerance and forgiveness. But it never preaches to its audience. The film makes us believe in these people. They are more than merely pawns who help move the plot forward. Every character gained my interest. I was genuinely interested in what would happen to them.Inarritu is proving himself to be one of the most gifted directors working today. He expresses the human condition in a lyrical and poetic way that hasn't been done since Ingmar Bergman.Brad Pitt and Cate Blanchett star as Richard and Susan an American couple visiting Morocco. Susan gets into an accident. While travelling on a tour bus, she is hit by a bullet. A terrorist attack is the immediate response. But things aren't that black & white. Richard must now do everything he can to save his wife.Adriana Barraza plays Amelia, an illegal alien who has been watching an American couple's children. She has requested the day off so she can attend her son's wedding in Mexico, but, on the day of the wedding finds that she is not longer able to have the day off as the children's parents are unable to come home.Amelia now decides to bring the children with her as her nephew, Gael Garcia Bernal, drives them into Mexico.Zohra (Wahiba Sahmi) and Yasira (Fadmael Ouali) are children who must attend their father's sheep. The father has recently bought a rifle in order for his kids to kill wolves which attack the sheep. Soon the young boys get in trouble when a "game" goes terribly wrong.Finally there is Chieko (Rinko Kikuchi) a deaf-mute, who's mother died and has left her with her father. The two aren't on best terms leading Chieko to feel like an outsider and seek love and acceptance, sadly in all the wrong ways and with all the wrong people.How any of these stories connect I will leave up to you to go and see the movie but the connection are done in a masterful way. Inarritu slow builds the suspense in the scenes just enough to get our attention and then changes course going to another story.That technique may bother some, but, what it does is brings us closer to the story. He become more and more involved in these characters and their situations.It's hard to say who gives the best performance in the film. There isn't one character who stands out more than another. Everyone is equally effective. This is a true ensemble piece. It would however be a shame if "Babel" didn't recieve Oscar nominations for "Best Picture", "Director" and "Screenplay".Inarritu and company weave a story that will touch many people's hearts and challenge their minds. In the end, what more could we possible ask for.Bottom-line: One of the year's best films. Director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu shows the human condition in a way that hasn't been done since Ingmar Bergman. The characters come off the screen and become more than pawns within the plot. They are people we come and care about.

reviewText: After all the hype about Babel, I was truly disappointed. This movie is an exasperatingly conceited new film from Alejandro González Iñárritu. It is well acted and well filmed, but terribly overhyped and totally unreal. It is merely a smartly put together piece of near-nonsense: the kind of artsy, fartsy crap that student filmmakers put together and submit to local film festivals. The storyline is unbelievable and confusing. Three different stories in different parts of the world (Moracco, US/Mexico, Japan) running in parallel with the director's feeble attempt to make the audience believe that they are actually all one story.And what brings these 3 stories together? "It is a Winchester hunting rifle which a shepherd in north Africa buys and (rashly) entrusts to his two young sons, telling them to shoot jackals that menace his flock. There are no prizes for guessing if something terrible happens. One tragic shot from this rifle is, as they say, heard around the world. The fate of the shepherd and his boys (Mohamed Akhzam, Boubker Ait El Caid and Said Tarchani) is now welded to that of a desperately unhappy American couple (Brad Pitt and Cate Blanchett); their terrible situation causes the lives of a brash Mexican guy and his respectable aunt (Gael García Bernal and Adriana Barraza) to go tragically off course and everyone is enigmatically connected to a Japanese widower and his hearing-impaired teenage daughter (Kji Yakusho and Rinko Kikuchi)." quote taken by the review Peter Bradshaw from the GuardianDon't waste your money. This movie blows...

reviewText: I don't normally review novies here on Amazon, but had to put in my .02 on this film.  I was a little reluctant to watch this movie.  I am a marketing exec, wife, mother of two, soccer coach of 7 year olds, part-time student, keeper of dogs and horses.  When I sit down to watch a movie it is usually to have something on while I'm folding clothes or to RELAX.  I don't want to work too hard when I watch a movie, know what I mean?This grabbed me, though.  The movie is a composite of four interwoven tales, spanning a variety of cultures and life challenges: the American couple on vacation trying to cope with a great loss, the illegal Mexican nanny intent on getting to her son's wedding back in Mexico, two Moroccan sheepherding brothers and their father, the broken teenaged daughter of a wealthy Asian businessman.  I don't want to give anything away, so I wont go into plot details- others have given enough spoilers.I felt very empathetic toward all the chaacters.  I felt their emotions as I watched, and I think that is truly what makes this such an excellent film.  Sure, you can analyze the characters and plot and find all sorts of themes and lessons.  I'll leave that to you. You'll find lots of thought provoking material on what it means to have or have-not, when those times occur that no amount of money can fix things, how sometimes tragedy is so near and we know it, desperately so, and other times we have no idea what we almost lost and didn't. The filmography was amazing and I loved how they played with the timeline, piecing the stories together through interconnected moments.See it.  It is definately worth it.  I didn't find it pretentious at all, just very honest.  You can certainly just take it for what you see in it.  I have to say, one of my favorite movies I've seen in the past year or two.

reviewText: [...]First I want to start with the trailers.  All the trailers I saw are COMPLETELY misleading us... I was led to believe the movie was about an American couple in some Arab country who, because of the accident involving the gun, the husband is trying to save the wife but because no one speaks english, he cannot get the appropriate help, while another story happens somewhere else following the same protocol.Completely wrong.  Everyone understands each other (except for the Japanese girl who is absolutely impossible to comprehend) and there's no language barriers between anyone (the couple has a helpful man who translates for them).Brad Pitt's character had a helpful Muslim guy who spoke Morrocan Arabic and English, the Japanese girl knew sign language and could write, the Mexican nanny could speak English and Spanish, the Morrocan boys had no trouble speaking with anyone else in some other language.In my honest opinion, I think if the stories had been made out into separate short movies, all still connected, but in different segments, with much of the brutal scenes toned down by a lot, it could have worked out great, but all together like that, it was too painful to watch.First off, it's way too brutal. For seemingly no reason, the movie seems to grab you, rip at your heart, only to save you from breaking apart with a minor footnote that everything's going to be alright, then continuing to strip your heart sinew by sinew.It's brutal, but also tasteless and tactless.  First off, we have a little arab kid not even 13 masturbating in front of the camera while fantasizing about his cousin whose been putting on a show for him in the shower while he spies through a hole in the wall.We also have a Japanese girl who is apparently deranged and has no fear of being raped, wandering out in public with a miniskirt and flashing boys at the discotheque or w/e, then calling up a police detective involved in a case with her mother and stripping naked before him.We also have Brad Pitt dry-humping Cate Blanchett's character while she's urinating in a pan and slowly bleeding from the gunshot wound.We've also got the Morrocan kids getting involved in a police shootout and one of the boys getting shot and killed.We've got an old man and his old wife being brutalized by the police in Morroco.We've got two American kids nearly dying in the Texas desert because the border patrol gives up on finding them after a few minutes.We've got a nanny who has devoted her life to the two kids, and has spent 16 years in America, only to be deported when she's discovered to be an illegal alien, without being allowed to recover her 16 years worth of property, contacting her 16 years' worth of contacts, friends, or even to say goodbye to the two children she's loved for so long, just given a snotty-assed response by a snotty-ass immigration officer, "You should have thought of that BEFORE you snuck into our country [16 years ago]"The stories are so loosely connected as to be completely irrelevent, most especially in the case of Chieko, the Japanese deaf-mute girl.  Chieko's story and Amelia's (the Mexican nanny's) story have absolutely nothing to do with each other, or the shooting incident, save for the fact that Amelia is the nanny of Brad Pitt and Cate Blanchett's character's kids, and Chieko is the daughter of the man who originally owned the gun involved.The stories: For one, there's the deaf-mute Japanese girl who is sosexually starved that she's apparently gone insane, licking herdentist, flashing her crotch at boys at the J-pop, and literallyexposing herself to a police detective and forcing him to hold herbreast.  [...] Her story is in no way connected to all the others save for one piece of insignificant detail; her father owned the gun involved in theshooting of Cate Blanchett's character, then gave it to a Morrocanguide, who sells it to the guy whose kids are involved in the shooting.Two, the Morrocan kids get ahold of the gun from their father who buysit from the guide to shoot jackals who keep eating his goats. The kidsplay around with it, and remember the guide saying that the bulletscould travel 3 kilometers. They don't believe this, so they test it buyshooting at cars and buses on the road. They hit a bus, and obviouslyhit Cate Blanchett's character, then run away in a panic. This starts apolice investigation, in which the police began torturing the guide whooriginally owned the gun and his wife, and then leads to the family.The father discovers what the sons have done, and he beats them, thenthe kids take him to where they have hidden the gun. They find it, andon their way off, the police find them, and this leads to a shoot-outwhich leaves the older brother shot and presumably dead, with one ofthe officers wounded as the younger brother shoots back. He then breaksthe gun, and surrenders to the police, fearing they will shoot him.Next is the seemingly "main storyline" involving Brad Pitt's characterand Cate Blanchett's characters. Neither have names, or if they do,they are never given directly or indirectly to the audience. This storyis perhaps the dullest of them all, in which Cate Blanchett's characteris shot, and rather than turn back where they came, the tour guidebrings them to his village, where they sit there, slow down herbleeding, and then wait for hours for an ambulance to arrive. A manarrives to tell them the US embassy pulled the ambulance out at thelast minute to send a helicopter instead, meaning it will take evenlonger to arrive. All in all, nothing dramatic happens, except Cate'scharacter pees in a pan while Pitt's character kisses her sloppily and practically dry humps her, then she is taken out by helicopter and cared for at a hospital, where Pitt's character checks up on his kids and their Mexican nanny, where her story now begins.Now the Mexican nanny Amelia, whose story, I believe, is the mostcold-hearted and brutal at the hands of the filmmakers. She wants toattend her son's wedding in Mexico, but she has to care for thechildren and has nowhere to leave them. So she brings them with her,and her nephew Santiago drives them down across the border, where theyattend the wedding, and Santiago gets drunk.At nightfall, they are driving to the border, and the border patrol stops them as they realize he is drunk. When asked to pull over, he simply speeds through, and tries to lose the cops in the desert. Then he tells Amelia and the kids to get out of the car, he will lose the cops, and come back for him.The next morning, they are seen a dirty mess sleeping under somesharp-looking wooden desert things, and Santiago is nowhere to be seen.Not only that, they are completely lost. She tries to find a road fromwhich to signal for help, but cannot find any, so she leaves the girl(who is asleep) and tells her brother to look after them, she will findhelp and return. She finds a patrol officer finally, and tries to tellhim about the kids in the desert. He decides instead to arrest her, asapparently she was a suspect when Santiago sped away in the car.Finally he lets her lead him to the children, but she cannot find thembecause the desert sucks, or the children have moved. When she is shownbefore a border officer person, she is told the children were found,but would have been nearly dead. The officer then proceeds to brutallyrip into her, essentially saying it was her fault and that the childrencould have died (because, you know, in the desert, you'll die if anadult isn't sitting next to you), then he has her deported, herproperty confiscated, in true ancient Roman proscription fashion, not even allowed to say goodbye to her 16 years' worth of friends, family, and the two kids who in the end I believe still love her. Shenever sees the kids again and is left in abject poverty, trying to findher son back in Mexico who she finally does find at the very end of the movie.Also, people looking to see "Brad Pitt's best performance" should know that at most, he gets probably 10-15 minutes of screen time. And even that amount is nothing more than looking somber, or looking a wreck because his wife is dying.All in all in all, I really don't understand how to categorize the movie, or how even to judge it properly, but this was one movie that made me depressed for all the wrong reasons... it was very heavy on raw emotion, for seemingly no purpose other than to toy with the audience's emotion and make them cry.I don't understand why I hated it and thought it terrible, but I just do. Honestly, I believe you should go see it for yourself to truly judge. [...]I have to repeat what I said above: If each individual story were separated from the big mash it was mushed into for "Babel", and made into separate little movies, or even TV movies, and released separately, but still connected, it could have worked, and worked great (aside from the brutal parts which would need a heavy-hand toning down the gritty brutality).
summary: After much thought, deliberation, and reading of reviews good and bad, I think this is the absolute worst movie I have ever seen

reviewText: I hate to rain on anyone's parade but I found "Babel" to be over-hyped.  The cast is excellent and the concept intriguing.  Yet, somehow it doesn't quite make it.The essence of the film is that even very small actions can have consequences in other parts of the world.  A Japanese man visiting Morocco on a hunting trip leaves his gun with his guide.  The guide then sells the gun to a goat herder who, in turn, allows his children to carry it to shoot jackals.  The gun, however, is used for another purpose which, ultimately, has consequences in the US and Mexico.The concept is undoubtedly interesting.  Individuals are often unaware of the ultimate consequences of their actions.  The world is truly interconnected.Although the plot is compelling and the acting first rate, the film is not so rewarding.  I suspect that I had the film "Crash" in mind when I saw "Babel".  I thus had very high expectations.  "Babel" is certainly no "Crash".  Nonetheless, see the film.  It is certainly worth seeing.  Perhaps few films would rate well in comparison with "Crash".  My expectations were probably set unrealistically high.

reviewText: A Japanese hunter gives a riffle to a Moroccan tour guide in thanks of a pleasurable hunting trip.  That Moroccan man in turn sells the riffle to a family that lives nearby.  The man who purchases the gun tells his two young sons to use it to kill jackals that have been eating their animals.  The boys instead decide to shoot at a tourist bus, and thus begins this harrowing story that spans three continents and four families in pursuit of a greater truth; that we only want to hear what we want to hear and if we ever want to truly be understood we must be willing to listen.  `Babel' is an extremely well done film that, while never as a whole reaching levels of miraculous greatness, has moments of truly tender and emotional brilliance.I have been a fan of Inarritu ever since watching `Amores Perros' and so `Babel' was high on my list of films to see in 2006.  Surprisingly it took me a while to actually get to this film, but I finally did and I'm happy the time had come.  While it is probably my least favorite film but Inarritu (collectively) it actually has some of my favorite scenes he's ever directed (especially when involving the character of Chieko).  There are a few strands missing from this film in my opinion, a few loose ends that could have been tightened up; but overall this is a very rewarding experience.  This is one of those films I feel could have run a tad longer; maybe that would have deepened some of the sequences.The film centers around a stray bullet that hits an American tourist named Susan.  Susan and her husband Richard are vacationing in Morocco in an attempt to find some connection they lost between themselves.  Before they have a chance to manage anything more than a handhold Susan's life is put in danger.Back home in San Diego their children are being kept by their nanny Amelia.  Amelia is supposed to leave for her sons wedding in Mexico but due to the accident in Morocco she is left to care for the children longer than was expected.  Finding no one who can take the children she decides to take them with her to Mexico for the wedding.  All seems fine for a time but upon trying to reenter the country she is met with trouble.Back in Morocco the two boys responsible for the shooting are trying to keep their involvement a secret but when the gun is inadvertently traced back to their father they are forced to uncover the truth.  The families decision there after places them all at risk.The final storyline takes place in Tokyo where Chieko, a young deaf-mute Japanese girl, is coming into her own.  Feeling outcast by her peers, her disability becomes a hindrance to her emotional growth.  She feels jaded and left out as she watches her friends date and interact in ways she only wishes she could.  This in turn causes her to seek affections in the most obscene and inappropriate of manors, not ever really understanding the consequences.  This storyline is probably the most rewarding yet the most damaging to the film.  Instead of focusing on Chieko's father (the hunter responsible for placing the said riffle in dangerous hands) the film focuses on Chieko.  Chieko's story is the most fascinating and overall the most emotionally resonant of the entire film but it doesn't fit.  Each of the other three stories are all connected to one incident whereas Chieko's story feels like a complete deviation from the plot of the film.  It's not a terrible thing but in the end I feel like it takes a little away from the film.The performances within this film are all beautiful to witness.  Brad Pitt and Cate Blanchett are touching and so brutally honest with their characters.  Watching the guard surrounding Richard slowly fall away until he is stripped bare of any protectors and thus becomes raw emotion is so tragically effective.  The scene where he breaks down on the hospital phone is memorable and gripping.  Adriana Barraza is marvelous as Amelia, especially as the film draws to a close.  Her final scene with immigration is heartbreaking and so gritty and real.  The standout here though is the marvelous Rinko Kikuchi who is utterly flawless as Chieko.  Her character is so well fleshed out to where you feel her inner struggle and become one with her pain.  The scene where she breaks down after her advances to the police officer are turned down is so painful yet so immaculate you can't help but embrace it to the full.  It is probably my single favorite scene in the entire cinematic year that was 2006.The point behind `Babel' is that we, as humans, don't take the time to truly listen.  What I found so wonderful about this film is that really, other than Richard and Susan's situation, language barriers really play no part in the lack of understanding.  True, with Chieko there are some who don't know sign language and thus must read her writing to communicate, but at least they have that.  No, in `Babel' the lack of understanding comes mostly from the selfishness that engulfs us.  Quite frankly we too often don't want to listen.  When the police are mercilessly shooting at the Moroccan family instead of allowing them to explain and or surrender, it's not language gaps that prevent them from rationally dealing with a problem, it's stubborn pride.  When Amelia and her nephew are stopped at the border it's not language gaps that prevent them from explaining their situation, its blatant assumption and carelessness.  When Chieko accuses her father of never listening to her you get the impression that no one ever truly has listened to her and that's what makes her breakdown so much more moving; it was a long time in the coming.`Babel' teaches us a powerful lesson about relationships with others and the responsibility we have as family, friends and in general human beings to take the time to truly listen to others.  If we weren't so preoccupied with our own interests then maybe this world would see fewer tragedies.
summary: Undeniably powerful; a film that will move you to action...
Title: N/A

reviewText: There are four vignettes here - two in Morocco, one in Southern California and Mexico, and one in Japan.  It's the path of a rifle that loosely binds the tales together.  [Some of it's a stretch, frankly.]  I enjoyed three of the plotlines, especially the Japanese stuff.  Rinko Kikuchi is spectacular as a deaf mute teenager, and it's a treat to see Kji Yakusho.  [Who can forget him inShall We Dance?] Director Alejandro González Iñárritu does his best work in those scenes I think.  As spectacular as the Moroccan mountainside scenes are, the passages from Kikuchi's viewpoint are fabulous...as are his sequences that get to the heart of the unrelenting crush of Tokyo life.Like Iñárritu and writer Guillermo Arriaga's partnership in21 Grams, Babel is anything but linear in its telling.  Tony Gilroy does the same thing inMichael Clayton (Widescreen Edition)andDuplicity, but he gives you little cues ("2 weeks earlier"...that type of thing).  González Iñárritu and Arriaga don't do that.  Until you catch on it can be confusing.  The viewer needs to piece the sequence together.  After you get it, it's neat to watch it all fall together.The one part of the film I soured on: any time Brad Pitt appeared on screen.  I'm not anti-Brad Pitt.  I've enjoyed him in many things.  But here, he's visibly straining To Be Meaningful in an Important Movie.  It's off-putting.  Whenever Iñárritu went back to him, I twiddled my thumbs, looked elsewhere...and waited for the focus to shift back to characters for whom I cared.
summary: I liked 'Babel' more than I thought I would...except for the parts with Brad Pitt

reviewText: BABEL tells four interconnected stories in four languages. The link for all is a Winchester rifle that once belonged to a Japanese businessman. Perhaps the most compelling of these situations involves that man's teen daughter, a chronically depressed deaf mute who's obsessed with a police detective.Director Alejandro González Iñárritu gives us enough information along the way to hold our interest, revealing facts when necessary or timely. For instance, we don't learn of the rifle's origin and its chain of owners until well after an unintended injury occurs.There's troubling events in all of this film's locations: Morocco, Japan, Mexico, and to a lesser extent, California. A mostly unknown cast give naturalistic performances, some of which will haunt you long after the credits start to roll.Highest recommendation for a brilliant motion picture.

reviewText: Some people are divided by this movie, but they would have to admit that it evokes some emotional response in the end (whether positive or negative). I personally was moved. I loved Inarritu's "Amores Perros", I wasn't fond of "21 Grams", but "Babel" is Inarritu's best achievement as a filmmaker. The scope of the story, with the different locations (Morocco, Japan, Mexico, and U.S.), and cultures are connected by a string of events (starting with a gunshot). The tagline well fits the theme in the movie to "Listen". You can see the many difficulties anyone from any country can experience from a lack of communication in the world and also between families. We live in a world that supposedly has crossed language and culture barriers, but the reality is far from that. Yet humanity still tries and sometimes finds deep connection through compassion. This movie made me ponder this among other things. Some people may think of this movie as similar to the Academy award winning "Crash", but "Babel" felt more heartfelt to me. Also "Babel" was more aesthetically appealing (cinematography and score), and not as forceful in giving a message. I was pleasantly surprised when "Babel" received the most nominations at the Golden Globes. Especially with two well deserved `Supporting Actress' nominations for Adriana Barraza and Rinko Kikuchi. I hope that "Babel" is as well received at the Academy Awards, because it's definitely one of the strongest films I've seen in years, let alone 2006.

reviewText: First of all the acting was wonderful. Honestly (even the one's acting in the plot I have a problem with at the bottom). I enjoy movies where the plot jumps a great deal but this was a little out there. Maybe someone can fill me in. What was the family tragedy? Was watching with my brother and we kept going back and forth figuring things out (I like that because you have to pay attention). Did Brad's character have an affair? I never understood what it was she could not forgive him for. At one point we thought that maybe the movie had twisted and they were on their trip after loosing the two kids but then how could they when they called the Nanny from Morocco (Nope). Maybe Brad's evil had something to do with the tragedy in Japan (Nope)? The situation in Morocco to me is a possible turn of events. The Nanny with the two kids, eh, could happen. People have done dumber things. But... there is NO one other than the nanny? NO friends, family, no one? How many parents would go to Morocco and leave their children with only the nanny responsible and for how long? What ruined the movie for me was the sub plot of the Japanese girl. What in the world? For one thing there is the issue with the mother. Way to much weight put into that story line. Two, the girl has a problem keeping her panties on because of the mother? Father? Mad because she is mute? Wants to have sex? Detective gets note explaining???? Dad finds daughter and what makes for a very touching father daughter moment??? The end...  What the heck just happened? That added no value to the movie for me and did not even leave me with anything to ponder. Well yes it did but that was to wonder what the heck was that about. Yes we found out how the gun fit in but...but...but. I know not all movies tie up all the loose ends and I even enjoy that in most movies. I liked Babel and the nanny goes to Mexico I can deal with. But the whole Japanese portion of the movie not only does not tie up any loose ends but just unraveled a movie that I otherwise enjoyed.

reviewText: I found BABEL to be hypnotic to the point that I wanted to see much more, and more. It touches not only your heart but also  all the senses in your body and it will make you think twice about humanity.EVOCATIVE! COMMANDING! DISTURBING! THOUGHTFUL! MARVELOUS!  Babel is as close to a masterwork as you can get.  Delicate elements of cinema are used harshly and sensibly; the music is HAUNTING, the actors are utterly compelling and every single one of them -  stars or not - is brilliant. The story is universal and timely.  We the people of this wonderful global community need each other. Every single one of us matters and are responsible for what is going on across the earth.  Slowly we are melting into ONE, regardless of space or culture - regardless of our desires or stubbornness.  Babel shows us how judgmental and irrational people can be, how innocence is lost and violence is present in every aspect of our life.I loved how Iñárritu touched upon power and authority.  Babel spans different cultures from various parts of the world and the authorities are extremely dissimilar.  Just pay attention to the Moroccan Police Squad, the Japanese detectives and the United States border patrol. Amazing what you will discover, and it is up to you how will you interpret it. The sexual awakening of the characters,  Amelia's sensible kiss at the wedding of her son,  Yuseff's father's reaction to the shocking news and the "walk of desperation" in the hot California desert will never leave my psyche. It is etched there forever like any major event in my life.Once in a great while we have a film that stands out from the rest, that is not only artistic and emotionally trenchant, but also goes beyond our expectations. BABEL holds up a large mirror for all of us to gaze in and understand who we really are.Babel is a hymn to humanity, it is an elegy to our ONEness and interdependency.
summary: See BABEL.  Reflect, meditate, be concerned. It is a GREAT Film.

reviewText: Even after watching this movie, I'm still not sure what I think.  Babel demands a lot of energy from the viewer but it doesn't even try to return the favour.  Four stories that don't seem connected at first glance basically end up staying that way.  There's merely small references here and there that supposedly bind them together, but sadly there's no real point to even portraying any of these four stories in the first place. They are merely sad segments of different people's lives in different situations.  The movie might have some merit if it was actually trying to tell four stories rather than four montages.  It's unfortunate that Cate Blanchett wasn't given the opportunity to shine in this movie because she is a truly amazing actress.
summary: Four stories. Three countries. One film

reviewText: Many reviewers have noted the similarity to Crash in  which seemgingly disparate people and events are somehow related.  Others have criticized the self-referential aspect in which the hum-drum is elevated to cosmic self-importance.  It's another consciousness-raising festival, Hollywood style, and we are supposed to discern deep thoughts and all sorts of hidden meanings while munching popcorn.  Several in line had never heard the Old Testament story from which the title came, proving once again that we are turning out a nation of cultural idiots. We are dealing here with an inability to communicate whether by speaking differnt languages or speaking without listening or saying things without meaning them or perhaps more likely, all our technology has falsely made us think that ease of communication is the same as the act itself.In movies like this the slightest question raises a host of possibilites. Is it even possible that these worldwide events could be related?  Brad Pitt is still searching for the BIG ROLE, the breakout movie in which he finally proves he is a "serious" actor (lol).  Alas, Richard comes across as, well, Brad Pitt playing Richard, which is fine for most of the viewing audience.  One can admire the intricacies of the film, the attention to detail, the thematic relationships (a little heavy at times) and the subtlety but in the end the sum of the parts is less than the whole.  Each vigenette (actually  movie within a movei - this thing is too long!!) attempts a variation on the theme and about halfway through one has an  inkling of how things will turn out.  We are asked to connect to our inner spiritual self which comes across as some global, vague transcendence.The Japanese vigenette seemed (and still seems) odd, out of place really.  The Moroccan story was the best of the movie. This is probably a two-week film since most of the moviegoers will jabber about how it touched them while thinking, God I can't believe I spent $10 on this thing. If it is like the theater where I saw the movie, there was much looking around and asking, "What does that mean?"  The house keeper, by the way, almost stole the show - much more effective than the big "stars".
summary: Is This The Future of Cinema?

reviewText: I don't know why some people had trouble following the movie. It is not uncommon for some movies to go back in time and then to current time. It was obvious in this movie, not a problem to me. Quite simply, a Korean man gifted a rifle to a fellow Moroccan hunter, who allowed his young children to use it, unsupervised. Then, when he learned the youngest boy shot an American tourist and she was barely  hanging onto life, the father attempted to disappear with both children. They were caught but the youngest was a bad ass who shot at the police and when they shot back, the good son was shot & killed. Lesson to the father who should have taken responsibility for non-supervision and turned in his son. The tourists' babysitter had good intentions toward the tourists' children but, she used poor judgment and came off as hiding something - pretending to look for a permission letter at the border, instead of just being honest, saying she didn't have one. She should have told them why she took them to Mexico. She knew her nephew was drunk and stupidly took a chance, with two young children who were not hers. He deserted the three in the desert and disappeared. She was caught and deported, after about 7 illegal years in the U.S.  THIS IS A MOVIE about all that went wrong because people did stupid or the wrong thing. The only thing that didn't make any sense to me was why the Korean girl was such a trampy slut. Sure, she lost her mother in her mid teens but, big deal, people lose a parent all the time and don't act like that. Why her father wasn't surprised that she was standing on the balcony completely naked - he should have told her to get some clothes on and been angry that she was behaving that way. The girl was just asking for trouble. It seemed to me that they wanted a naked component to the movie and had time left over so they added the girl. American writers/producers seem so obsessed with showing naked women. Anyway, she was disgusting to watch. The other actors gave great performances.

reviewText: An ominous shot in the Moroccan hinterlands echoes in a Mexican village, cracks across Tokyo`s metallic skyline.  Are the consequences of our actions so interconnected, so inextricable from one another?  According to Alejandro Inarritu`s masterful creation, `Babel,` the answer is yes.Few plots are as labyrinthine as `Babel`s,` and even fewer manage to remain as comprehensible and engaging as this one.  An impoverished Moroccan family of goat herders barters for a new hunting rifle to help protect their flocks.  The herder`s sons taunt each other into ever greater feats of marksmanship when a fateful target looms into view:  a tourist bus lumbering up a mountain highway.  His turn to trump his brother`s paltry aim, the younger son pulls the trigger and soon sets off an avalanche of unforeseen consequences.The stray bullet finds home in an embittered American housewife (Cate Blanchett), angered and confused as to why she and her husband (Brad Pitt) are sweating things out in such a desolate destination.  The renegade shot stops such musing short as she slowly bleeds out and her husband`s increasingly ugly American behavior takes over.  An American shot in an Islamic backwater...it must be `terrorists.`As the bus veers into a nearby village for medical assistance, the shot sounds an echo heard worlds away.  Tokyo police search out the original owner of the rifle, while the American couple`s children back in Southern California are shuffled off to their Mexican housekeeper`s (Adriana Barraza) Baja village for her son`s wedding.  Sound convoluted? Preposterous? Unlikely in the extreme?  As Innaritu`s skilled direction weaves the storyline ever deeper, your disbelief becomes thoroughly suspended as the improbable, the impossible comes to life.As Tokyo`s police track down the gun`s owner, his deaf-mute daughter (Rinko Kikuchi in a truly heart-wrenching debut performance) unloads a Pandora`s box of hidden pain.  Deprived a mother by suicide, Kikuchi`s character is adrift in a world that neither understands her nor she it.  The film shows that even when words are clear and intelligible, they rarely mirror the truth of our desires and needs.  Kikuchi`s character is a pathetic case in point.  Treated as an outcast by the speaking world around her, her hunger for human connection intensifies.  She screams for contact, yet nobody listens.  She finally resorts to the only language left her, her physical body, to convey her loneliness and hunger for connection.  Yet, those confronted by her glaring behavior and physical directness miss the deeper message.  Signals are misread, and meanings get lost in translation.  She, like all the film`s characters, gets lost in a babel of words bereft their true message.Innaritu`s film shows a human community stumbling ever further away from comprehension, from connection.  Botched transmissions and fumbled receptions clutter each frame. Lies overlap lies until words are but empty vessels, stripped of content.  In the village where Pitt`s character scurries helplessly, English-language television networks ramble on about `terrorist cells` and an `American tourist killed` (she survives).  When the Moroccan gendarmes descend upon the goat herder's family, misinformation swarms like flies.  The police thugs beat up those whose `answers` make no sense.  As the housekeeper returns from Mexico with her American charges, her nephew (the fiery Gael Garcia Bernal) engages in a verbal cat-and-mouse game with the border guards until chaos overcomes.  The housekeeper, with her limited English, is unable to clarify an otherwise straightforward situation.  Confusion spreads like a cancer and the consequences approach the catastrophic.Despite the cacophony of voice and miscue, `Babel` does not descend into absolute despair.  Innaritu does offer hope that understanding is still possible.  The children of this film carry its redemption.  Throughout the film, they knowingly and unknowingly set right the confusions adults sow.  The housekeeper talks to her American ninos in Spanish and they passively, instinctively comprehend.  In the Moroccan village, while parents and police turn to violence, the youngest son (Mohamed Akhzam in an amazing performance) ends the mayhem by divulging the truth the adults have failed to grasp.`Babel` ends painfully, tragically.  A boy chocks the wheel of violence but not without a horrible price.  A housekeeper saves her charges but loses her freedom.  A lonely girl threatens suicide.  What makes these moments all the more pathetic is that they could have been avoided.  Innaritu suggests our babel of tongues, customs, and walls deny us the chance of celebrating our common humanness.  The best we can hope for is support from those closest to us, namely our own flesh and blood.  The muted, misunderstood teen clings to her father, the hapless American tourists realize their children hold the keys to contentment, the deported housekeeper finds refuge in her son`s arms, and the Moroccan father grieves a murdered son, saved perhaps an even worse fate.While Innaritu`s political subtext may grate some viewers the wrong way (Are American lives worth more?), don`t let that scare you away from a provocative, thoughtful and emotionally enriching experience.  While the big names (Pitt and Blanchett) fill the film`s minor roles, it is the unknowns and child actors who deliver `Babel`s` masterful performances.  `Babel` celebrates those outside the Hollywood pale...the Bernals... the Barazas... the Kikuchis... the Akhzams.  Combined with Gustavo Santaolalla`s evocative soundtrack (a great follow up to his Brokeback Mountain work) and Rodriego Prieto`s lush, encompassing panoramas of Sahel scrabble and Tokyo steel, their all too human portrayals make `Babel` a film for the ages.

reviewText: Anyone who has read "The Emperor's New Clothes" knows it takes a little courage to disclose what we actually see and hear. when the rest of the world sees and hears somthing radically different.While the director is masterful at evoking tension, it tends to be unremitting, and the events depicted -- such as a child wringing the neck of a live chicken, a woman being shot randomly while sleeping on a tourist coach, or a lonely, deaf adolescent exposing her genitals to strangers in a cafe -- are generally off-putting. The film purports to make serious statements about violence, about the regressive impact of the press on society, about the randomness of human fate, but it falls flat. And why cast Cate Blanchett in the role she has here? She's been cast to play a corpse!Except for the thoughtful musical score, this film was physically revolting. I could only watch it for about half an hour before returning it to the video store -- and I rarely abandon a movie in midstream. A pretentious, overpraised, prurient work.
summary: One of the worst films I've ever seen

reviewText: Communication is vital to human survival; be it diplomatic, within family units, or at border crossings. There are tons of examples of deadly ends that have resulted due to miscommunication. And this is the premise for BABEL, a film winning (and probably destined to win) many movie awards. Although I think this is fine, I do think it a tad unfair for a couple of reasons.First is that comedies are often pushed aside at these award shows in favor of dramatic roles. I point this out because this year LITTLE MISS SUNSHINE shone brightly with many award nominations but won too few. Comedic timing is probably one of the toughest achievements when it comes to script and acting, and to simply pass them by is the biggest shame in my estimation. Which brings us to Babel...Although thought-provoking and interesting, Babel isn't the monolithic film accomplishment I was expecting. After its multiple wins at Cannes and its Golden Globe pick-up for Best Picture, I was expecting a righteously perfect film. I did get a good film, an enjoyable one. But legendary? Above Little Miss Sunshine? I don't think so.Stories are about people, and Babel has that and a bit more. Perhaps too much more. Similar to CRASH in composition, Babel tells its story via a triad. The first is through the eyes of Richard (Brad Pitt) and Susan (Cate Blanchett), a married American couple on holiday in Morocco. Well, not really a holiday. They are there to try and save their marriage after the SIDS death of an infant son. Both feel equal amounts of guilt and blame toward the other. While driving in a vacation bus with other tourists, Susan gets hit by a bullet fired from a hillside by a ten-year-old Moroccan kid and his elder brother. Richard, forced into the role of a caring husband, must now try and save his wife's life while in the middle of nowhere and with limited communication skills in this foreign land.The second part of the triad takes place in Southern California and concerns Richard and Susan's two surviving children as they await the return of their parents from overseas. Amelia (Adriana Barraza), an illegal Mexican immigrant, watches over their kids and needs to go to a wedding in Mexico. Unable to find another babysitter for them, she reluctantly crosses into Mexico with the kids thanks to her cousin Santiago (Gael Garcia Bernal, THE SCIENCE OF SLEEP), a reckless man with a short fuse temper. Once in Mexico, everything goes fine. The wedding is beautiful and original in appearance. But crossing back over the border into the U.S. presents some nearly fatal results.The third and final part of the triad involves a deaf-mute Japanese teenager named Chieko (Rinko Kikuchi). Battling with her mother's recent suicide and her own growing sexuality, Chieko struggles to be understood in a world that's alive with sounds she'll never hear nor understand. Her father was also a great big game hunter and once gave a nice, new rifle to one of his guides as thanks for a successful hunt; the same gun used to shoot Susan in Morocco.There's a fourth leg to this story, too (not really a triad now, is it), in that the Moroccan boys and their family are unfortunately involved in the shooting of the American through their own foolishness and the illegal obtaining of a high-powered rifle (which was supposed to be used to kill jackals that eat their goat herd).The big problem with the entire story is that it's built on such a grand scale that it just can't stand up under its own, great weight ...especially when comparing it to something like Little Miss Sunshine (which got the audience VERY intimate with its characters). That's not to say that Babel isn't watchable or even good. It is both. I'm glad I saw it. But on par with Little Miss Sunshine and the like? I don't think so.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Babel" wasn't easy to watch.  The objective wasn't to entertain.  Early on, one member of my family left the room because the reality was so intense.  I was fascinated because the patina and shine surrounding most commercially ambitious films was missing from "Babel."  I am drawn to the reality of movies like this, in the same sort of way I begin watching TV by starting at the top of the cable channels and working my way down to the networks.  These days the networks feel overly contrived and fake, which is why they are usually my last choice."Babel" was about alot of things, and it was certainly thought provoking on many levels.  Of all the themes worthy of discussion, I'm left thinking about the fragility of my modern, sheltered, western existance.  The main characters in this movie are all just a random moment and a little bad luck and/or bad judgement away from total disaster.I agree with most of the previous reviewers who found beauty in the directing, acting, camera work, and audio.  Even the extras, such as the tourists on the bus whose growing fear is palpable, added to many dramatic moments.  Most important, I think the movie was able to put us as nearly as possible (while sitting on my couch in the safety of my home) into the experiences of the main characters. Particularly memorable were the scenes with the brilliant young actress playing the deaf/mute.  The sound came and went, the camera shook back and forth in dramatic anxiety, and the visual stimulation was overwhelming, as if we were experiencing what the young woman was experiencing.  I understood the dreadful lonliness she was feeling while surrounded by hundreds of people in the club and on the streets of Tokyo.Now, several days after seeing "Babel," I continue to contemplate the roles played by the various human beings who come in contact with the main characters in each of the three primary sub-plots.  These entirely random intersections have a huge impact on what unfolds. First the unwitting antagonists: the stupid boys with the gun, the ugly men on the bus, the moron at the border station, the drunken nephew, the dentist, and the insensitive, distant father.  These people cause the main characters to loose their footing and fall into peril.Next, the miraculous strangers, who, when all appears to be lost, kindly (heroically?) step between the main characters and death.  The two best examples were the Moroccan bus driver who invites the critically injured woman and her husband into his house while finding a doctor and a phone, and the police lieutenant, who somehow finds a way to be tender and understanding, probably preventing another suicide.Finally, I'm left thinking about what desperation will do to people and how we respond.  The babysitter went to great lengths after a series of bad decisions, to endure the desert to protect the kids.  Moments after their petty despute where the couple ably demonstrates their indifference for each other, the husband does everything he can to save his wife.  She cries - not when the pain gets too intense, but when he tells her he loves her.  And finally the young woman who exposes and denudes herself, in a desperate attempt for a response of any kind from a world in which she finds herself completely alone.I appreciate movies like this where the objective is to create art and tell a story as honestly as possible, where doing so the best way you know how, will inevitably preclude commercial success.

reviewText: Babel, trying to imitate the wonderful style of Academy Award-winningCrash (Widescreen Edition), is a touching, thought provoking story of the world and its peoples.The movie itself has an amazing premise--a husband, Richard Jones (Brad Pitt) decides to take his wife, Susan (Cate Blanchett) for an exotic vacation to Morocco. But things are hardly exotic, as they will soon find out. From Morocco the story transitions to California, where a Mexican-American maid is left in charge of the Jones' children while the couple are on vacation.Babel continues to introduce new cultures as Mrs. Jones receives a wound to the shoulder while riding a bus through the deserts of Morocco. From there, a Moroccan family's role in the crime is unraveled, and the story of a Japanese deaf-mute begins.This movie is truly touching, as all of the subplots intertwine and a feeling of bittersweet catharsis is felt.This movie should be an absolute must for everyone; your life will be changed after watching this movie.

reviewText: There's a profound sense of dread throughout this that makes the viewer fear what is coming next. It's not a horror film, though horrific things happen. It doesn't make for comfortable viewing. And it takes awhile for the tapestry that links the three disparate stories to come together. Impressive film-making, I guess, and the captions add to the authentic feel. The message: a feel good theme about home and family. Brad Pitt doesn't have a lot to do here, though he's billed as the star. Others in the film make much more of a splash, such as the Latinos and the Japanese.

reviewText: What does a poor Moroccan sheepherding family, an affluent white American couple on vacation and a mute teenage Asian girl in Japan have to do with each other? According to the plot of this film, everything!The '06 release of the film `Babel'* appears to possess the perfect title for a storyline involving individuals who are unknown to each other yet subtly interconnected through a series of random acts of friendship, indifference and stupidity. The intention being that what we do is not done in a vacuum, every action has the potential to affect others in a myriad of ways. It's a world of endless possibilities.'Babel' does explore a rather fascinating subject matter which in and of itself makes for an interesting watch. The difficulty with the film is that it attempts to weave three storylines into one coherent, enjoyable whole. The connection between the three is ultimately accomplished, but they unfortunately don't command equal interest in the viewer thus detracting from the overall flow and continuity of the movie. I found myself becoming distracted and unfocused when the film left the central theme involving Brad Pitt and Cate Blanchett and then reconnecting when the plot returned to the two main stars in Morroco. This imbalance damages the film, but it's still well worth the watch nevertheless.*Babel is the ancient Biblical site where God scattered mankind throughout the world by changing our one common tongue into a myriad of languages. This inability to communicate with each other not only separated us geographically, but has served as a major cause of alienation ever since.
summary: "Why Did We Come Here?" ~ Confusion, Conflict, Chaos & Connection In A Harsh And Alienated World

reviewText: Babel is worth watching as the director does a great job of interweaving the three storylines. Never give a weapon as a gift to a Moroccan.2. Always have a doctor onboard a tour bus.3. When taking American kids across a border, make sure your nanny is a legal alien and the driver is not drunk.4. Dead mute teenagers in Tokyo are toasted out of their minds.Other than that, this movie makes perfect sense. Also, having lived in Tokyo for decades it captures Tokyo life quite well but in over 20 years of living there I've yet to find an apartment building with a 24-hr. doorman let alone any doorman. This was either a very wealthy area of Tokyo that has adopted some Western-style security or it's one the movie world made up.

reviewText: This is a very good movie in some ways and not so good in others. The cinematography and acting are top notch. the various sub-plots are interesting and grounded in reality, i.e. there are no overly dramatic events that make the movie unbelievable. The scenery and acting really make you feel the emotion in the characters. You can't help but feel the deep pain of the deaf girl who is looking for the wrongs things in the wrong places. You feel like you are watching 3 or 4 movies at once because the converging plots are so different from one another, and yet, each sub plot is emotionally packed and very well acted in its own right.On the other hand, I believe the filmmaker bit off a little more than he could chew. Some of the extended shots are designed to emphasize the setting of the particular plot...and it works very well, however, it also tends to slow the movie down more than necessary. And since this type of movie tends to be a little slow and hard to follow to begin with, any storyline or technique that slows it even further is detrimental. Maybe more of that time should have been spent on the great acting.The story does come together in the end and each of the sub-plots are closed out in an acceptable manner, however, it all seemed a little anti-climactic. Tough to put my finger on it, but the end did not live up to the build-up. That may, in fact, be a very realistic ending to the plot, but it did not provide any dramatic punch.To close, this is a good movie that is very well acted and filmed. The downside would be the overly ambitious approach, the slow pace at times, and the somewhat uninteresting ending.

reviewText: This movie was about poor decisions more than anything else, and their consequences in foreign lands.  It reminds me of Crash, but wasn't nearly as heavy-handed in its message.  Then again, nor did the eventual connections between the four seemingly disparate story lines resonate as much- the links are pretty tenuous, and once they were revealed, I thought, "So what?"  Particularly pointless was the Japanese storyline, although it was interesting and kept me in suspense before it let me down.The entire movie was very well acted, and the healthy number of novices gave the picture an authentic feel.  Big names like Brad Pitt and Cate Blanchett kept their egos in check and were just a couple more people in the mix, struggling to face the challenges this world can offer the unprepared and unsuspecting.  There is a lot of pain in this film, and the actors in Babel sold me every ounce with their performances.The landscapes were beautiful, too, and help to convey the desolation and helplessness that pervades the entire film.  National Geographic might as well have provided the footage, it was so gorgeously shot.
summary: Poor Decisions Are Universal to All Cultures

reviewText: I have read some professional reviewers who are put off by Babel's scene construction in its storytelling. They also feel that the characters don't connect emotionally. I don't know what film they saw, but please see Babel. It is one of those films that helps to break down the barriers which have us viewing people of different nations as "the other."I don't believe that Brad Pitt has that elusive x factor to allow him to carry a movie like Tom Hanks and George Clooney possess; ie. star quality. It has nothing to do with degrees of talent. His forte is as a character actor and he more than proves it in this ensemble production. He is terrific in Babel. He should go the way of Kevin Bacon who knew this fact about himself and became a character actor. Bacon's move in this direction has resulted in his being a valuable part of many subsequent high profile quality films instead of eventually winding up in forgotten straight-to-video cheapies. I think Brad Pitt would be very successful with such a career move. Babel is a seminal film for our time in the need for us to see all peoples (not governments) as human beings with fears, troubles and who share the same general hopes and dreams.

reviewText: I saw BABEL last night and I was deeply moved to tears by the end of the movie. This film is not only compelling and riveting but complicated as well. The movie interlocks four different stories all rolled into one. I didn't think that the movie was going to be as good as I thought it was. The beginning dragged on a little but it quickly picked up the pace and from then on it moved at full speed to the climatic ending. Brad Pitt (who I've never been too fond of) is excellent as is Cate Blanchett as his long suffering wife who is at the face of death through the entire film. Everyone in the cast is fantastic, the acting is great as is the writing and directing. Gael Garcia Bernal as a small time punk with his share of an evil streak is very good although he's hardly in the movie is always good to watch. The kids nanny mexican actress Adriana Barraza and the Japanese girl (her name escapes me) are both fantastic in their roles. BABEL is a movie that one must see with an open mind, eyes and ears. Is not your average type of movie. It is one that will leave you thinking long after the credits roll in the screen. It is a story about humans that experience highly complex situations in their lives and somehow it involves and touches more than one family. Highly recommended for those who appreciate movies that pick at their brains and forces them to take a deep, hard look at the world in which they live in and examine their lives. The plot of this movie is one that can happen to anyone at any time and the scary thing is that it has happened before and more than likely will happen again.

reviewText: Blog, Slog and Chug.  I don't know how else to describe this film!  At times it seemed gripping but for the life of me I cannot figure out why anyone would deem it Oscar worthy.  Brad Pitt's performance is okay, but nothing to write home about.  The film at first seems to show a domino effect of happenings but soon they just all sink down into slow, depressing ooze.  I was so looking forward to watching it only to be disappointed.  Kate Blanchett is rather stunning in acting like a distant, removed woman who tries to forge ahead in life while still carrying an extreme load of emotional baggage.  The happenings after the rifle shot are not even realistic as every person in this desert land owns some kind of firearm to begin with.  Some very sick happenings with a child, or at least what appear to be, was enough to make me sick but not enough to make me feel like it contributed any relevance to the storyline.Brad Pitt is an actor I can never take seriously in roles like this.  Maybe it is the whole Brangelina thing, who knows.  He is a second rate actor at best and I think that the likes of Adrien Brody would have done a much better job.If you like it great, give it a chance.  I did, I just did not care for it and felt it went so overboard in the "look everything is bad bad bad" department that I was ready to watch snow on channel 3 just to get back to...reality.

reviewText: This is a good movie with comments to make on many levels.  It shows the heartache that one couple has to overcome after losing a child.  There is a certain poetic justice about the stupidity of a nanny putting herself in jeopardy, a pleasant, caring woman who has been breaking the law for 16 years.  Then there is the story of two boys who play their rifle games oblivious to what harm they are doing to other people, completely innocent people.  Does their culture create people, even young ones, who are so irresponsible?  Today's newspapers confirm the film's answer . . a resounding yes.  And, attached to the film's plot by a very slender thread, the Japanese girl has pain that can be felt by everyone watching her, including the audience.I wouldn't necessarily call this film enjoyable, but it is an enlightening and mesmerizing film.  It also has probably the best role that Brad Pitt has ever had or played.

reviewText: Director Alejandro González Iñárritu took 4 interlocking stories, unfolding in Mexico, the US, Japan, and Morocco, to make this film, but there is a communication breakdown, not unlike what happened to the builders of the tower of Babel. Though it had multiple nominations, and won for best score, the sum of the parts somehow equals less than the whole.The stories don't really connect in any meaningful way, and three out of four don't even work as vignettes. The young goat herders who shoot Cate Blanchett are not believable. Actually, they do a good job, acting-wise, but I just didn't buy that they wouldn't realize that if they shot at a busful of tourists, they might actually hit one.Brad Pitt's character is a real jerk, and perhaps was meant as a metaphor for our foreign policy. He is understandably frustrated in his attempts to get his wife to a hospital, but tells the other passengers on the bus that he will kill them if they leave without him. If he is meant to learn a lesson, such as the importance of family, he doesn't ever seem to get it. He is just relieved that his wife and children don't die. Brad Pitt did a good job, acting-wise, but the writing didn't give him much to work with. I never understood what exactly he was doing out in the desert, and what was the trouble in his marriage about? Why was he such a jerk? Why should we care?The Japanese story is the only one that can stand on its own, but its connection to the other stories is the weakest of all. A young Japanese woman struggles to connect though she is deaf, and saddened by the recent death of her mother. Rinko Kikuchi was nominated for an Oscar for best supporting actress (along with Adriana Barraza), and she really deserved it. Tokyo looks like an amazing place.This film was really a good effort, with great cinematography, an Oscar winning score, and fabulous locations. Acting was first rate, but what was it trying to say? I can think of three examples where this kind of format worked to much better effect: Crash, Traffic, and Syriana. These covered the themes of Race, Drugs, and Middle East Politics, respectively, but the interlocking stories supported and intensified each other. And the scenes from Babel in Mexico were great, but if you want to see the vibrancy and energy of Mexico portrayed, I recommend Et Tu Mama, Tambien.
